bioghist.p: William C. Anderson, John Alexander Anderson and Harrison R. Anderson were all Presbyterian clergymen. William C. Anderson (b. 1804) was the eldest son of John Anderson. His entire adult life was spent in the ministry with the exception of two short periods: 1843-1844, when he was professor of rhetoric and belles-lettres at Hanover College, Hanover, Indiana; and 1849-1854, when he was president of Miami University at Oxford, Ohio. From 1873 to 1879 he was president of Kansas State University. He was also a member of Congress from Kansas, serving from 1878 to 1890, and was later appointed by his college friend Benjamin Harrison to serve as Consul General to Egypt. Harrison R. Anderson was pastor of the Fourth Presbyterian Church in Chicago. and was Moderator of General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., 1951-1952. John A. Anderson, son of William C. Anderson, was born near Pigeon Creek, Washington County, Pennsylvania, on June 26, 1834. He graduated from Miami University in 1853 and was ordained in the Presbyterian ministry four years later.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Rev. H. R. Anderson, Moderator of the General Assembly. Materials include: correspondence of H. R. Anderson (includes notes from Dwight D. Eisenhower and Herbert Hoover); announcements, notes, sermons, and minutes, from Anderson's time at Fourth Presbyterian in Chicago; printed sermons and anniversary booklets from several churches; printed prayers and drafts of manuscripts and printed articles, several related on church union and related matters; and a transcription of a letter from H. R. Anderson to his parents, written while he served as a chaplain in the U.S. Army during World War I. The collection also includes: W. C. Anderson diaries from 1846, 1847, 1856, 1861, and "A Sketch of My Service in the Ministry," an 1841 European travel diary; letters of Rev. John A. Anderson , including letters from Benjamin Harrison; a book of signatures of members of Congress (collected by Anderson's wife); and cabinet cards, photographs, and several daguerreotypes (including Jane Mary Anderson, the wife of William C. Anderson).
